text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: when you’re on a trial we can sometimes blame the new drug for that symptom and then that drug gets a black eye. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So companies want to make sure that you’re good to go on and they’re not going to get a black eye because there’s something going on that’s not related to what they’re doing. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Yes, understand. Doctor: So that’s important that we get the pulmonary evaluation, what they’re thinking. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: It’s likely that we probably need new pictures to sort of see what your liver is doing. And I think it’s time in some ways because you know the Enzalutamide is not controlling your PSA, and you’re ARV7 positive it’s likely that if we got more pictures we would see more cancer. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: I need to know what’s going on with your lungs because some of the treatments that we would talk about have toxicity to the lungs as one of the main side effects. Patient: Okay.

text: Family Member: So how soon would you try to start the new treatment Doctor: I think there's like a good at least two to three week washout you know we got to let that one get out of your system. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: -and then start the new thing. Family Member: Oh I didn’t realize that. Doctor: Otherwise you can get drug interaction- Family Member: Okay. Doctor: -that's not what we want. Patient: Do I throw away? Doctor: No, no no no. Don't go throw anything. We'll take your leftovers, but at the moment just keep it in case we need to come back to it this year. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Don't, don't do anything. Family Member: Okay.

text: Patient: Yeah, no, you explained it, someone explained it that there’s - when chemo starts - it’ll be a blood test prior the chemo and a blood test after. And, uh, the leaving the timings out of it because I don’t really recall. And then, then roughly a week before the next cycle, there’ll be a blood test, then the chemo, and then, we’ll say within a week, I guess it’s another blood test. And that’s to keep an eye on, uh, all of these numbers? The blood cell or the white counts, etc.? Doctor: Yeah, I mean, so chemotherapy certainly can drop your blood counts and put you at risk for infection. Uh, so, we wanna make sure that, uh, how low is it to sort of - if you did have a fever, are we worried; are we not worried? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, and before we give you your next dose, we need to make sure that your counts have recovered (cell phone alert) Patient: Okay. (softly) Doctor: So, those are all, you know, the typical thing is with chemotherapy, you see myself or C__, you know, one day, and then we pick a day, the next day or the next day, to come in and get the chemotherapy. So, we’re really trying to do a safety evaluation that yes, it’s safe. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: T_ may be able to do it all in one day. I’m not a big fan of all in one day. Uh, just because, uh, it’s got a lot of hoops, and if you don’t have it. So, tend to see you on a Tuesday. Is everything clear? And, then we pick a day and you just go and get it. Patient: Alright. Doctor: And then that day, the people upstairs have cleared it for you. Your, uh, counts are okay. That your time is upstairs is shortened because - - Patient: I won’t have to wait for results. Doctor: Correct.

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah? That was okay? Patient: They put a, they put a little thing in the nose. Doctor: Okay. But I see you don’t need it. So that’s a good sign. text: Patient: Which way did it get it? From the left side or right side? Doctor: The biopsy? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Ooh, I want to say left. Uh, I think it was the left, and then they did the special stains underneath the microscope, and, you know, looked for actual prostate stains, and it was positive on both of them. So now the question is, you started your hormone shot back up, and you’ve kind of been on it the whole time. It’s just you were delayed a little bit on one day, one of them, and now it’s you need another medicine. But I want to make sure that you are well healed from your pneumonia before we go ahead and do that. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Probably, you know, another several weeks or so until you feel like you’re back on your feet, uh, and over the flu, the pneumonia, and all that, but we think you’re going to need a set of pills to kind of help keep the prostate in check. Patient: What kind of pills? Doctor: So these are FDA-approved pills called Xtandi, which is the trade name. Uh, they’re four pills once a day, and their primary goal of how they work is it’s, it’s like a big hormone pill again. So it’s to help your shot work better. It also is approved by the FDA because it helps you live longer. No cures. Same as we were before but we need to get a handle on all these things in the lung. In the same way, you’re also a candidate for chemo to tell you the truth. Uh, so chemo’s in the mix as well, but the majority of folks I think, and I’m not saying you do, but my patients tend to prefer pills before going on to chemotherapy, and I think way back when we initially again reconnected you were not in so much favor of chemo, uh, as he’s already shaking his head, but I want to bring that up again because at some point we may need to go to chemo. So I want to put that out there still. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but we do have a set of pills. Now, the good news is every time there’s an approved medication, you know, we’re at K______, so we do a lot of clinical studies. So one of our studies is to use that same medication and see if we add a second pill to half the group whether you’d respond better. So I like that study because it’s all pills and no one gets a placebo when you’re thinking about the Xtandi pills. Everyone is on the regular pill that is approved. The question of the placebo versus the other drug is extra. Okay? So I’m not sure if that makes sense or if you’ve got questions with that, but we’re going to try hard to have you be, you know, considered for that study. Uh, I want you to still recover well from your, your hospitalization, but, uh, but that’s in the works for us to consider. The other part is either way, however we move forward, there’s another study, which is a registry study, called, Iron Man. Uh, not that you become iron man- Patient: Hum. Doctor: but that all your experiences as to what’s happened to you get captured. And that means you write out and answer questionnaires. I write out and answer questionnaires. Uh, and then about once a year we take some blood to see what’s happening uh in terms of new research. Uh, and that participation’s pretty cool because a lot of other men around the world are, are participating. And so we get answers from guys from Australia, Ireland, uh, you know, England uh, gosh, Canada, France, so all of that. So everyone’s experience will be captured. And they’re all like you, in the same boat. So we hope you consider that as well. Uh, but I think what we might do is workup to make sure that you’re eligible for all that stuff. I want to introduce you to M___, who’s our research nurse, uh, who just wants to say hi, and then I think we’ll have you come back in a couple weeks when you feel like you’re a little bit stronger.

And they’re all like you, in the same boat. So we hope you consider that as well. Uh, but I think what we might do is workup to make sure that you’re eligible for all that stuff. I want to introduce you to M___, who’s our research nurse, uh, who just wants to say hi, and then I think we’ll have you come back in a couple weeks when you feel like you’re a little bit stronger.

text: Patient: Exactly. Doctor: So you know radiation is tough. It helps the pain but it’s always something for something, Patient: Yeah. Doctor: not something for nothing, so there’s some side effects there. And you got a lot of radiation. Patient: So the question there being then probably safe to go back on the supplements? Doctor: Yes. Family Member: On some of them. I would gradually reintroduce them if I was you. Doctor: Yes. I agree with you. Patient: And I also had a question about that proton treatment that they have in B___. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: Um Doctor: Not ah truly applicable to you at this point. That’s great for if you were just newly diagnosed with your prostate cancer or if you have some specific area on your spine. You obviously just got the radiation to there but if you know you’re a baby, for example, and you had a really tiny spinal cord, and you have this cancer next to it, a proton would be the perfect treatment. For adults, it’s a little harder to know what is better than the standard. So you know you hope maybe if you got protons you wouldn’t have had so many side effects. That’s possible. But it’s not as mainstream I think as we’d like to see it. At some point now when they’re really up and running and more patients will get experience, we’ll probably get a better sense of that. But for now I think you’ve got the best treatment which was those three areas in the spine and then your pelvis. Family Member: But is this proton more precise than-?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
